P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

GENREAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want mentioning the reasoning of your predictions as well as how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P etc).  Here, ONLY output the labels and its associated predictions and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    P: 0.xx
    not_P: 0.xx
    P_or_Q: 0.xx
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!}

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occured before.
        Note that changing the probability of one given variable for one consistency check will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that all changes  
        your correction needs to ENSURE that it still passes other consistency checks too.
        If there were no violations found then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
        P: 0.xx
        not_P: 0.xx
        P_or_Q: 0.xx
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

For the questions provided, I will estimate the probabilities based on the context and potential outcomes regarding the Trump family and the likelihood of armed conflicts with China leading to significant casualties. 

1. **P (Trump Family Nominee)**: I believe there is a moderate probability that a member of the Trump family will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidency. Given Donald Trump's previous presidency and ongoing political influence, I estimate this probability at around 0.60. 

2. **not_P (No Trump Family Nominee)**: This would be the complement of P, so it will be approximately 0.40. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of Trump Nominee)**: Since this is essentially similar to P, I will assign it the same probability of 0.60. 

4. **Q (Armed Conflict Leading to Deaths)**: Given the geopolitical climate and historical tensions, I estimate a lower probability of armed conflicts leading to at least 100 deaths before 2050. I will assign this a probability of 0.25.

5. **P_and_Q (Both Events Occur)**: Here, I need to consider the joint occurrence of both events. Assuming some correlation between the two events, I might estimate this around 0.15.

6. **P_or_Q (Either Event Occurs)**: Given the probabilities of P and Q, I can estimate this using the formula: P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, it would be around 0.60 + 0.25 - 0.15 = 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not P)**: This would require that there is an armed conflict leading to deaths while no Trump family member is nominated. I would estimate this at around 0.10.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P)**: This is a conditional probability, and I would estimate this at around 0.30, assuming that if a Trump family member is nominated, the likelihood of conflict might slightly increase due to heightened political tensions.

In summary, the relationships between these probabilities are interconnected, particularly between P and not_P, and between P and Q. I will ensure that the estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided.

cons_P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 8,000Mt?
cons_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

metadata.background_info:
For further context and motivation for this and other questions in this tournament on nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields, and a list of such questions, see here.
The total yield across all arsenals depends on both the number of weapons in states' stockpiles and the yield of each of those weapons. This tournament has or will soon have other questions on the number of nuclear weapons that'll be in states' stockpiles and the largest yield weapon that'll be possessed.
Stockpiles include deployed, reserve/nondeployed, and retired (but still intact) warheads, and both strategic and nonstrategic weapons. If states that aren't currently nuclear-armed are nuclear-armed when the latest estimated published in 2029 are made, their stockpiles can count towards positive resolution.

For the questions presented, I will analyze the likelihood of each event occurring based on the political landscape, historical context, and the nature of the questions. 

### P: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
I estimate this probability to be relatively high, around 0.65. Donald Trump remains a significant figure in the Republican Party, and his family members have also been active in politics. The dynamics of the Republican primaries could favor a Trump family member, especially if Donald Trump decides to endorse one of them. 

### not_P: Will no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
Given the high probability assigned to P, the probability of not_P would be 1 - P = 0.35. This reflects the uncertainty surrounding other potential candidates who could emerge in the Republican primaries. 

### para_P: Is it possible that a Trump family member will secure the Republican nomination for the US Presidency in 2024?
This is essentially a similar question to P, so I would assign a probability of 0.65 here as well, as it aligns with the likelihood of at least one family member being nominated. 

### Q: Will armed conflicts between the United States and the People's Republic of China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
I estimate this probability to be around 0.30. While tensions between the US and China are high, actual armed conflict leading to significant casualties is less certain. The geopolitical landscape often leads to diplomatic solutions rather than military confrontations. 

### P_and_Q: Will both of the following occur: (1) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (2) Armed conflicts between the US and China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
I would estimate this probability to be 0.20. This reflects the combined probability of both events happening, but considering they are not directly dependent, I expect the joint probability to be lower than either event occurring independently. 

### P_or_Q: Will either of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024? (b) Armed conflicts between the US and China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
This would be higher than either individual probability, likely around 0.75, as it captures the likelihood of either event occurring independently. 

### Q_and_not_P: Will both of the following occur: (1) Armed conflicts between the US and China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050, and (2) no member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
This probability would be lower, around 0.10, reflecting the combined nature of two events that are somewhat independent but also influenced by the broader political context. 

### Q_given_P: Given that a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, will armed conflicts between the US and China lead to at least 100 deaths before 2050?
This probability could be slightly higher than Q alone, perhaps around 0.35, as a Trump family member's nomination might influence international relations and military actions.

cons_P.title: Will the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact reach 40% of the Electoral college before 2030?
cons_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if at least five reliable media sources report that states representing at least 40% of Electoral College votes have signed the NPVIC before 2030.

metadata.background_info: The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact is a an agreement among states to award all of their electoral votes to the candidate with the highest popular vote, conditional on enough states agreeing that the total electoral vote count would secure a majority in the electoral college. In effect, the agreement means that if enough states sign on, the popular vote will determine the outcome of presidential elections. So far states representing 196 electoral votes have signed on, which is 73% of the way to the 270 required to obtain a majority in the Electoral College.

In this scenario, we are evaluating several forecasting questions related to the potential outcomes of the 2024 US Presidential election and the implications of armed conflicts between the United States and China. The questions are interrelated, particularly with respect to the potential nominations of the Trump family and the likelihood of armed conflicts leading to significant casualties.

1. **P (Trump Family Nominee)**: This question revolves around whether a member of the Trump family will be the Republican nominee for the presidency in 2024. Given Donald Trump's prominence in the party and the possibility of his family members being involved, I estimate a relatively high probability for this event, say around 0.65. This reflects the current political landscape and Trump's continued influence.

2. **not_P**: Conversely, the probability that no member of the Trump family will be the nominee is naturally the complement of P. Thus, it would be approximately 0.35. This estimate considers the potential for other candidates to emerge within the Republican Party.

3. **para_P**: This question asks if it is possible for a Trump family member to secure the nomination. Since P is estimated to be quite high, I would also set para_P around 0.65, indicating that it is indeed possible given the current context.

4. **Q (Armed Conflicts with China)**: The question of whether armed conflicts with China will lead to at least 100 deaths is complex. Given the geopolitical tensions, I would estimate this probability at around 0.40, acknowledging the potential for escalation in conflicts.

5. **P_and_Q**: This question requires both events to occur. Assuming some level of independence between the Trump family nomination and potential armed conflicts, I would estimate this at 0.25, reflecting a moderate intersection of these probabilities.

6. **P_or_Q**: This question will resolve positively if either event occurs. Using the formula for the union of two events, I would estimate this at around 0.75, combining the probabilities of P and Q while accounting for their intersection.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This question focuses on the occurrence of armed conflicts while no Trump family member is the nominee. I would set this probability lower, around 0.15, reflecting the potential for conflicts but also the possibility of a Trump family member being nominated.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability asks whether armed conflicts will lead to 100 deaths given that a Trump family member is the nominee. I would estimate this at around 0.45, as the nomination could influence international relations and the likelihood of conflicts.

Overall, these estimates reflect the current political climate and the complexities of international relations. I will ensure that these estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided.

P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

cons_P.title: Will more than 30% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
cons_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 30% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

metadata.background_info:
The Merriam-Webster Dictionary defines augmented reality (AR) as
an enhanced version of reality created by the use of technology to overlay digital information on an image of something being viewed through a device (such as a smartphone camera)
Some expect AR devices to be much more prevalent in the future. Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about augmented reality in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
By 2050 pretty much everyone will be wearing smart glasses for augmented reality, and eventually these glasses will replace a lot of phones (no one will carry a wallet in 2050).
According to a PEW survey, 85% of US adults said they owned a smartphone in 2021.
